captions.text:
Let's say you're me, and
you're in math class,

and you're supposed to be
learning about factoring.

Trouble is, your
teacher is too busy

trying to convince
you that factoring

is a useful skill for the
average person to know,

with real-world applications
ranging from passing your state

exams all the way to
getting a higher SAT score.

And unfortunately,
does not have the time

to show you why factoring
is actually interesting.

It's perfectly
reasonable for you
to get bored in this situation.

So like any reasonable
person, you start doodling.

Maybe it's because your
teacher's soporific voice

reminds you of a lullaby,
but you're drawing stars.

And because you're
me, you quickly

get bored of the usual
five-pointed star
and get to wondering, why five?
So you start exploring.

It seems obvious that
a five-pointed star

is the simplest
one, the one that

takes the least number
of strokes to draw.

Sure, you can make a
start with four points,

but that's not really a star
the way you're defining stars.

Then there's a
six-pointed star, which

is also pretty
familiar, but totally

different from the
five-pointed star

because it takes two
separate lines to make.

And then you're
thinking about how,

much like you can put
two triangles together

to make a six-pointed star, you
can put two squares together
to make an eight-pointed star.

And any even-numbered star with
p points can be made out of two
p/2-gons.

It is at this point
that you realize

that if you wanted to avoid
thinking about factoring,

maybe drawing stars was
not the greatest idea.

But wait, four would be
an even number of points,

but that would mean you could
make it out of two 2-gons.

Maybe you were taught
polygons with only two sides
can't exist.

But for the purposes
of drawing stars,
it works out rather well.

Sure, the four-pointed star
doesn't look too star-like.

But then you realize you can
make the six-pointed star out

of three of these
things, and you've

got an asterisk, which is
definitely a legitimate star.

In fact, for any star
where the number of points

is divisible by 2, you can
draw it asterisk style.

But that's not quite
what you're looking for.

What you want is a doodle
game, and here it is.

Draw p points in a
circle, evenly spaced.
Pick a number Q.

Starting at one point,
go around the circle

and connect to the
point two places over.
Repeat.

If you get to the starting
place before you've

covered all the points, jump to
a lonely point, and keep going.
That's how you draw stars.

And it's a successful game,
in that previously you

were considering running
screaming from the room.

Or the window was open,
so that's an option, too.

But now, you're not only
entertained but beginning

to become curious about
the nature of this game.

The interesting thing is that
the more points you have,

the more different ways
there is to draw the star.

I happen to like seven-pointed
stars because there's

two really good ways to draw
them, but they're still simple.

I would like to note here
that I've never actually left

a math class by the
window, not that I

can say the same
for other subjects.

Eight is interesting,
too, because not only are

there a couple nice
ways to draw it,

but one's a composite
of two polygons,

while another can be drawn
without picking up the pencil.

Then there's nine,
which, in addition

to a couple of
other nice versions,

you can make out
of three triangles.

And because you're
me, and you're a nerd,

and you like to
amuse yourself, you

decide to call this kind
of star a square star

because that's kind
of a funny name.

So you start drawing
other square stars.

Four 4-gons, two 2-gons, even
the completely degenerate case
of one 1-gon.

Unfortunately, five pentagons
is already difficult to discern.

And beyond that, it's very
hard to see and appreciate
the structure of square stars.

So you get bored and
move on to 10 dots

in a circle, which
is interesting

because this is the
first number where

you can make a star as
a composite of smaller

stars-- that is, two boring
old five-pointed stars.

Unless you count asterisk
stars, in which case 8 was two

4s's or four 2's
or two 2's and a 4.

But 10 is interesting
because you can make it

as a composite in
more than one way

because it's
divisible by 5, which
itself can be made in two ways.

Then there's 11, which can't
be made out of separate parts
at all because 11 is prime.

Though here you
start to wonder how

to predict how many
times around the circle

we'll go before
getting back to start.

But instead of exploring
the exciting world

of modular arithmetic,
you move on to 12,

which is a really
cool number because it
has a whole bunch of factors.

And then something
starts to bother you.

Is a 25-pointed
star composite made

of five five-pointed
stars a square star?

You had been thinking
only of pentagons

because the lower numbers
didn't have this question.
How could you have missed that?

Maybe your teacher
said something

interesting about prime
numbers, and you accidentally
lost focus for a moment.
I don't know.
It gets even worse.

6 squared would be a 36-pointed
star made of six hexagons.

But if you allow use
of six-pointed stars,

then it's the same as a
composite of 12 triangles.

And that doesn't seem in
keeping with the spirit
of square stars.

You'll have to define
square stars more strictly.

But you do like the
idea that there's

three ways to make the
seventh square star.

Anyway, the whole theory
of what kind of stars

can be made with what
numbers is quite interesting.

And I encourage you to explore
this during your math class.

comments.author: Kevin Robert

comments.text:
We used to do basic versions of this in elementary school, where we had two 
lines perpendicular to each other and would make lines up one line and 
across the other, and connect the lowest point with the point farthest 
right, then second lowest, second farthest, and so on. I went a little 
crazy, and I could probably find 20 or so different designs in my attic if 
I really wanted to.﻿

comments.author: Wizard Garber

comments.text:
+Eric Stucky That is precisely my point. She went off on a thread of 
inquiry and missed this one, while making the comment that the hexagram 
made of two stars was the only way it was made.
comments.author: Wizard Garber

comments.text:
That is true, but the other stars she was drawing are not of the same type, 
so she is clearly laying out a particular (different) type of object for 
investigation. I didn't mean that other types of stars aren't worth 
investigating, but just that she didn't "leave it out" because it wasn't 
what she was talking about here. We cannot study everything at once; there 
are too many things :P
comments.author: Eric Stucky

comments.text:
+Eric Stucky
The 5 pointed star she was drawing is of the same type.  It is a unicursal 
pentagram.
comments.author: Wizard Garber

comments.text:
The unicursal hexagram is of a different type than the stars she was 
considering, because Q is not constant; labeling the points 
counterclockwise and starting at the top, the first Q is 2 but the second Q 
is 3.

I don´t know if you still read the comments, but my mother is a 
kindergarden teacher here in Germany, and yesterday she asked me if I knew 
something cool to do with circles, so I told her your way to draw stars. 
And she wasn´t sure if the kids would get it, so she just squeezed the 
basic principle at the end of the time. But then the kids loved it and 
started to experiment around, so I think I´ll point her to more of your 
videos and perhaps next time they´ll get to do one of you doodles and talk 
it through more. ﻿

comments.text:
That's pretty much the point of all her videos. It's also the problem of 
teaching math in general. Nobody gets dry math, unless you're able to 
visualize the math in some way or form. Sure you can learn it by heart, but 
you'll never be able to recognize it in practice when you actually need it.

comments.text:
Great to see someone making a video on this topic. I remember doing this 
when I was in school many years ago. I was trying to make various n-pointed 
stars without lifting the pencil in each case. Triangles and squares don't 
count. I managed n=5 all the way to n=20 or so, with the exception of n=6.

comments.text:
Let's say you're me and you have no social life. You've watched TV, you've 
eaten your brownies, and your friend went back home. Quite lazily you open 
your laptop, lay in bed, and check if any people you've subscribed to 
uploaded any videos. You remember watching about science last night. You 
Type the name in the search bar, misspelling a lot even though there are 
only two words, and you find a magic little annotation. You click it and it 
leads you to a series of videos about doodling and shapes.

this was a game I used to play, imagining stars on occasion as being 
non-integer sided polygons... This was very personal. Now apparently the 
world knows about it. :-) I really enjoyed your "twelve tones"... This... 
breaks my heart... Not really.. I'll simply have to think of a 
hyperdimensional analogue.... You're very inspiring for sharing it...
